Content: Muslims celebrate Eid-ul-Fitr after concluding the month of Ramazan, today. Ramazan month is the 9th month of the Islamic calendar. As the new moon was sighted, Islamic devotees all over the world commenced celebrating Ramazan festival. Issuing a congratulatory message, President Maithripala Sirisena says the fasting period led by the Islamic devotees, withholding worldly pleasures, sacrificing, indulging in religious rituals and offering onesâ€™ own earnings to the poor and the helpless symbolizes the spirituality common to all South Asian religious philosophies. He added that a religion that teaches to experience the hunger of others and to learn to sacrifice to merge with others is, indeed, an invaluable gift to society. In this long journey of human civilization, we come across all the religious practices, beliefs and philosophies of the world. The President pointed out that thus the common string of humanity is much further than the religious followings. Issuing a message, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe says the annual observance of Ramazan is of profound significance to Muslims everywhere. It centers on the spirituality, humanistic ideals and social principles that lie at the heart of Islam. The Premier noted that these are the values that have guided the Sri Lankan Muslim community, which has long been an integral part of the nation. Issuing a message on Ramazan festival, Opposition Leader Mahinda Rajapakse said that true Muslims respect all faiths and religions. He added that they love the motherland to the highest noble end. Speaker Karu Jayasuriya states that Muslims in Sri Lanka have been part and parcel of a local culture spanning many centuries.
